The 'orange' (specifically, the 'sweet orange') is the fruit of the citrus
species Citrus [[hybrid name|Ã]] {{zwsp}}sinensis in the family Rutaceae. The fruit of the Citrus sinensis is called sweet orange to
distinguish it from that of the Citrus aurantium, the bitter orange. The orange
is a hybrid, possibly between pomelo (Citrus maxima) and mandarin (Citrus
reticulata), cultivated since ancient times.

Probably originating in Southeast Asia, oranges
already were cultivated in China as far back as 2500 BC. Arabo-phone peoples
popularized sour citrus and oranges in Europe
http://websites.lib.ucr.edu/agnic/webber/Vol1/Chapter1.htm and
then, Spaniards introduced the sweet orange to the American continent in the
mid-1500s.

Orange trees are widely grown in tropical and subtropical climates for their
sweet fruit, which can be eaten fresh or processed to obtain juice, and for the
fragrant peel. [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-
bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?10782 Citrus sinensis information from NPGS/GRIN]. Ars-
grin.gov. Retrieved on 2011-10-02. They have been the most cultivated tree
fruit in the world since 1987, Morton, J.,
[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/orange.html Fruits of Warm Climates]
(1987) Miami, FL, pp. 134â142. and sweet oranges account for approximately
70% of the citrus production. [http://www.citrusgenomedb.org/organisms Organisms].
Citrus Genome Database In 2010, 68.3 million tonnes of oranges were grown
worldwide, particularly in Brazil and in the US states of California
and Florida.

The origin of the term orange is presumably the Sanskrit word for "orange tree"
(à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤à¤à¤®à¥, nÄraá¹ga), whose form has changed over time,
after passing through numerous intermediate languages. The fruit is known as
"Chinese apple" in several modern languages. Some examples are Dutch sinaasappel [http://en.bab.la/dictionary/dutch-
english/sinaasappel sinaasappel â English translation â bab.la Dutch-English
dictionary]. En.bab.la (2011-03-24). Retrieved on 2011-10-02. (literally,
"China's apple") and appelsien, or Low German Apfelsine. In English, however,
Chinese apple usually refers to the pomegranate. [http://www.food-dictionary.com/definition/Chinese-
apple.html]
